jparsec.ephem.planets

Class OrbitalElement

  • java.lang.Object
    • jparsec.ephem.planets.OrbitalElement
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class OrbitalElement
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    An adequate class for storing orbital elements in the FK5 system.

    This class is suitable for storing orbital elements of planets, comets, asteroids, and space probes. Elements should be referred to mean equinox and ecliptic of Earth, for a given equinox.

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    T. Alonso Albi - OAN (Spain)
    See Also:
    Ephem, Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • OrbitalElement

        public OrbitalElement()
        Constructs an empty OrbitalElement object.

      • OrbitalElement

        public OrbitalElement(double sma,
              double mean_lon,
              double ecc,
              double perih_lon,
              double asc_node_lon,
              double incl,
              double ref_time)
        Constructs an OrbitalElement object giving the values of the main fields. Argument of perihelion is set to perihelion longitude minus ascending node longitude. Mean anomaly is set to mean longitude minus perihelion longitude. Mean motion is set to Constant.GAUSS / (sma * Math.sqrt(sma), assuming a massless object in heliocentric orbit.

        Is is necessary to set also the reference equinox and frame (J2000 and FK5 by default) to get correct ephemeris.

        Parameters:
        sma - Semimajor axis in AU.
        mean_lon - Mean Longitude in radians.
        ecc - Eccentricity.
        perih_lon - Perihelion longitude in radians.
        asc_node_lon - Longitude of ascensing node in radians.
        incl - Inclination in radians.
        ref_time - Reference time (usually perihelion time) as a Julian day.

      • OrbitalElement

        public OrbitalElement(java.lang.String nom,
              double sma,
              double mean_lon,
              double ecc,
              double perih_lon,
              double asc_node_lon,
              double incl,
              double ref_time,
              double motion,
              double equinox,
              double init_time,
              double final_time,
              float mabs,
              float slope,
              OrbitalElement.MAGNITUDE_MODEL magModel)
        Constructs an OrbitalElement object giving the values of most of the fields. Argument of perihelion is set to perihelion longitude minus ascending node longitude. Mean anomaly is set to mean longitude minus perihelion longitude. Frame is FK5.
        Parameters:
        nom - Name of the object
        sma - Semimajor axis in AU.
        mean_lon - Mean Longitude in radians.
        ecc - Eccentricity.
        perih_lon - Perihelion longitude in radians.
        asc_node_lon - Longitude of ascensing node in radians.
        incl - Inclination in radians.
        ref_time - Reference time (usually perihelion time) as a Julian day.
        motion - Mean motion in radians/day.
        equinox - Reference equinox as a Julian day.
        init_time - Begin of applicable time as a Julian day.
        final_time - End of applicable time as a Julian day.
        mabs - Absolute magnitude.
        slope - Magnitude slope.
        magModel - The model to apply for the magnitude.

    • Method Detail

      • parseMoonOrbitalElement

        public static OrbitalElement parseMoonOrbitalElement(MoonOrbitalElement moon_orbit,
                                     double jd)
        Transforms a MoonOrbitalElement object into an OrbitalElement object, correcting for longitude and periapsis precession rates to certain Julian day for subsequent ephemeris calculation.
        Parameters:
        moon_orbit - Input object.
        jd - Julian day when the elements should be calculated, i.e. subsequent calculation time.
        Returns:
        Output object.

      • getAsteroidMaximumMagnitude

        public double getAsteroidMaximumMagnitude()
        To obtain the brightest apparent magnitude an asteroid could reach. Note the magnitude returned depends on the magnitude model selected for the orbital elements.
        Returns:
        Brightest magnitude.

      • getCometMaximumMagnitude

        public double getCometMaximumMagnitude()
        To obtain the brightest apparent magnitude a given comet could reach.
        Returns:
        Brightest magnitude.

      • getCometMaximumMagnitude

        public double getCometMaximumMagnitude(double JD)
        To obtain the brightest apparent magnitude a given comet could reach in a given date. Note the magnitude returned depends on the magnitude model selected for the orbital elements.
        Parameters:
        JD - The Julian date.
        Returns:
        Brightest magnitude.

      • getApparentMagnitude

        public double getApparentMagnitude(double distance,
                          double distanceFromSun,
                          double phaseAngle)
        Returns the apparent magnitude of this minor object. Note the magnitude returned depends on the magnitude model selected for the orbital elements, and it is not corrected for the phase angle of sun light. In case the object has phase close to 0 the value returned here will be the magnitude for the side illuminated by the sun, not the one being observed.
        Parameters:
        distance - Distance from Earth.
        distanceFromSun - Distance from Sun.
        phaseAngle - The phase angle in radians.
        Returns:
        The apparent magnitude using the corresponding magnitude model.

      • changeToEquinox

        public void changeToEquinox(double jd)
        Transforms the set of orbital elements to another equinox following Astronomical Algorithms, based on IAU 1977 precession.
        Parameters:
        jd - The Julian day of the new equinox in TT. Reference time (epoch) is unchanged, only inclination, argument of perihelion (and its longitude), and ascending node longitude are changed.

      • FK4_to_FK5

        public void FK4_to_FK5()
                throws JPARSECException
        Transforms a set of elements from FK4 B1950 to FK5 J2000, following Meeus, chapter 23. Reference time (epoch) is unchanged, only inclination, argument of perihelion (and its longitude), and ascending node longitude are changed.

        To transform elements between Bessel equinoxes

        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the reference frame is not FK4 or the reference time is not B1950.

      • getNextPassThroughMeanAscendingNode

        public double getNextPassThroughMeanAscendingNode()
                                           throws JPARSECException
        Returns the time the body pass through the mean longitude of the ascending node (for the equinox of the elements). It will be the approximate real pass if the orbit is unperturbed and the mean motion or inclination are not too small.
        Returns:
        The time as a Julian day in TT.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the orbit is hyperbolic, which is unsupported in this method.

      • getNextPassThroughMeanDescendingNode

        public double getNextPassThroughMeanDescendingNode()
                                            throws JPARSECException
        Returns the time the body pass through the mean longitude of the descending node (for the equinox of the elements). It will be the approximate real pass if the orbit is unperturbed and the mean motion or inclination are not too small.
        Returns:
        The time as a Julian day.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the orbit is hyperbolic.

      • getOrbitImage

        public java.awt.image.BufferedImage getOrbitImage(int w,
                                         int h,
                                         double scaling,
                                         double jd)
                                           throws JPARSECException
        Returns a simple sketch of the orbit as an image. The orbit should be an ellipse. For double stars north is up and east towards left.
        Parameters:
        w - The image width.
        h - Image height.
        scaling - Additional scaling factor if desired, otherwise set to 1.
        jd - The Julian day to mark to position of the orbiting body in red.
        Returns:
        The image.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        Test program.
        Parameters:
        args - Not used.
